results.content: Overall, this is a good course if you are looking to understand custom themes and WordPress pages. However, there are a few lectures that are really out of date. The lectures using INK framework and Foundations framework have coding that is now depreciated and it took a while to figure out how to set up the pages to work with the rest of the lectures.  There is a missing lecture as well called Dynamo Theme that was mentioned in the wrap-up summary video that is not in the main core of lectures. So that was a little bit of a bummer. But overall, Brad is an excellent instructor and I definately found this site to help as I continue learning how to build WordPress themes.

results.content:
PROS:
This course could've been like so many others where they briefly show you how to do something and then send you on your way. This course has you build multiple themes, so you can see various progressively complex theme renditions. It allows you to really get a feel for building themes, while seeing the instructor's efficient workflow.

CONS:
You mostly do the same things in the development of each theme, with little deviation, however you are introduced to a myriad of tools such as animate.js, hover.js, gridism, foundation, bootstrap, etc, and you do get a feel for the instructor's workflow, so it can also be seen as a plus. One thing I found a little concerning is that I never saw the instructor use wp_enqueue... to register his scripts and styles. Since the WordPress docs say that using enqueue is the proper way to use scripts and styles, I wonder if I'm being taught the proper way to build a theme.
results.content_html:
PROS:
This course could've been like so many others where they briefly show you how to do something and then send you on your way. This course has you build multiple themes, so you can see various progressively complex theme renditions. It allows you to really get a feel for building themes, while seeing the instructor's efficient workflow.

CONS:
You mostly do the same things in the development of each theme, with little deviation, however you are introduced to a myriad of tools such as animate.js, hover.js, gridism, foundation, bootstrap, etc, and you do get a feel for the instructor's workflow, so it can also be seen as a plus. One thing I found a little concerning is that I never saw the instructor use wp_enqueue... to register his scripts and styles. Since the WordPress docs say that using enqueue is the proper way to use scripts and styles, I wonder if I'm being taught the proper way to build a theme.

It is clear that the instructor is knowledgeable of the content  covered in the course. What is also clear is that the instructor has no idea of how to properly teach these concepts. This is not a course of teaching, this course is about copying and pasting and going off to find the proper information about what was displayed on your own. If you just copy and pasted all of the code from this course you will not learn anything of substance and will only be able to perfectly recreate the projects. 

 You will not have a better understanding of the concepts behind creating a WordPress theme. You will have an idea of how some things work and you will have to do research to find out why the instructor copied and pasted  huge lines of code where he did, only to give a very casual overview of what that code does.  The instructor continuously saying "refer to the official documentation" make this course seem  very unprofessional and rushed. 

If there were better explanations for why things were being done in this course I could give it a better rating, but this is the instructors style and he doesn't feel like explaining anything in depth. At the end of this course there will be many things you don't understand, so be prepared to do additional research as this in not a complete guide.

results.content:
This course was not what I expected. There are several things wrong with it.

A: It's written completely from the point of view of someone who is used to web server setup. His tiny lesson on getting WordPress set up came with invalid and incomplete information on getting the system setup on one's home computer. It's only because I used to work in web administration that I was able to figure it out - after three hours of trying. The lessons after are not so much lessons as "hurry up and do what I do and you'll create a theme too".

B: He goes so fast, I had to pause the video every few seconds so I could back up, catch up, as well as try to figure out when my code went wrong - of which there are still three areas where I used his code and still had the same problem.

C: He has the LOUDEST keyboard on the planet. It overrides what he says and drove me so crazy I stopped the course and will ask for a refund. 

I'm very disappointed  because I do want to learn to create WP Themes. I'll look for a different course.

My suggestion - save the your money on this one. Try another instructor or and find something for free on YouTube.

results.content:
This course is very good for specific things, and bad otherwise.

If you've seen the instructors other courses and videos then you already know what to expect, it's exactly like his usual stuff.

The course is a walkthrough of multiple projects with follow-along coding, very little explanation, not necessarily the best practices. But for getting quick project experience under your belt it's a 10/10. Personally I think that's invaluable, and that's why Brad's one of my favorite instructors.

But if you're looking for methodical and clear explanations on WordPress, then you will definitely not find that here. This course is project heavy but very light on explanation. You'll be coding along while doing your own research for why or how things work.

Another problem with this particular course that happens throughout, are that his browser window overlaps his code editor. And he skips between the two very quickly after typing, so you constantly have to pause and rewind the video to view the code he actually typed so you can type it and / or see it for yourself.

In short: If you like Brad's other courses and videos, then this is more of the same. It's great for building actual things and learning that way.

If you're looking for a more traditional course, with good explanation of how things work, rather than projects follow along with very little explanation, then I definitely don't recommend this course.

results.content:
I really love that this course shows how to actually build projects that can be utilized.

There is a distinct lack of explanation to a lot of the code, however.  A lack of explanations about the PHP code aside, there is a lot of neglect in differentiating between PHP functions and WordPress functions.

If you do not have a very solid understanding of HTML5, CSS3, and (especially) PHP then I'd say this course is not for you.  If you are fairly comfortable with the languages, then this course is great for practical application. 

It's just a shame that I have to buy two courses to understand WordPress developing:  This course for multiple projects with real-world applications, and another course to understand the code demonstrated here.
